Unit 1: Introduction to Statistics

Lecture 1: What is Statistics?

Lecture 2: Probability Redux

Law of Large Numbers, Central Limit Theorem

Let X1,…,XnX_1, \ldots, X_nX1​,…,Xn​ be independent and identically distributed (i.i.d) random variables (r.v.). Let μ=E[X]\mu = \E[X]μ=E[X] the expectation and σ2=V[X]\sigma^2 = \V[X]σ2=V[X] the variance of these random variables.

We define the sample average of our XiX_iXi​ as:

Xˉn=1n∑i=1nXi\bar{X}_n = \frac1n \sum_{i=1}^nX_iXˉn​=n1​i=1∑n​Xi​

Law of Large Numbers (LLN):

(1.1)Xˉn→n→∞P,a.s.μ\tag{1.1} \bar{X}_n \conv{\P, a.s.}\muXˉn​P,a.s.n→∞​μ(1.1)

Where P\PP designs convergence in probability and a.s.a.s.a.s. convergence almost surely.

Central Limit Theorem (CLT):

(1.2)nXˉn−μσ→n→∞(d)N(0,1)\tag{1.2} \sqrt{n}\frac{\bar{X}_n - \mu}{\sigma} \convd \mathcal{N}(0, 1)n​σXˉn​−μ​(d)n→∞​N(0,1)(1.2)

Equivalently, we also have:

n(Xˉn−μ)→n→∞(d)N(0,σ2)\sqrt{n}(\bar{X}_n - \mu) \convd \mathcal{N}(0, \sigma^2)n​(Xˉn​−μ)(d)n→∞​N(0,σ2)

If nnn is not large enough to apply the CLT, we have Hoeffding's inequality. If X∈[a,b]X \in [a, b]X∈[a,b] almost surely, then

P[∣Xˉn−μ∣≥ε]≤2exp⁡(−2nε2(b−a)2)\P[|\bar{X}_n - \mu| \geq \varepsilon] \leq 2\exp\left(-\frac{2n\varepsilon^2}{(b-a)^2}\right)P[∣Xˉn​−μ∣≥ε]≤2exp(−(b−a)22nε2​)

Properties of normal distributions

Linear transformation: given a random variable X∼N(μ,σ2)X \sim \Norm(\mu, \sigma^2)X∼N(μ,σ2),

(1.3)∀a,b∈R,aX+b∼N(aμ+b,a2σ2)\tag{1.3} \forall a, b \in \R, aX + b \sim \Norm(a\mu + b, a^2\sigma^2)∀a,b∈R,aX+b∼N(aμ+b,a2σ2)(1.3)

We can therefore standardize any normal distribution:

(1.4)Z=X−μσ∼N(0,1)\tag{1.4} Z = \frac{X - \mu}{\sigma} \sim \Norm(0, 1)Z=σX−μ​∼N(0,1)(1.4)

We therefore have:

P[u≤X≤v]=P[u−μσ≤Z≤v−μσ]\P[u \leq X \leq v] = \P\left[\frac{u-\mu}{\sigma} \leq Z \leq \frac{v-\mu}{\sigma}\right]P[u≤X≤v]=P[σu−μ​≤Z≤σv−μ​]

The standard normal probability is also symmetric, which means:

P[Z≥x]=P[Z≤−x]\P[Z \geq x] = \P[Z \leq -x]P[Z≥x]=P[Z≤−x]

The quantile of order 1−α1-\alpha1−α of a random variable XXX is the number qαq_\alphaqα​ such as:

(1.5)P[X≤qα]=1−α\tag{1.5} \P[X \leq q_\alpha] = 1 - \alphaP[X≤qα​]=1−α(1.5)

Types of convergence

Let (Tn)n(T_n)_n(Tn​)n​ be a sequence of random variables, and TTT a random variable (which can be deterministic).

Convergence almost surely:

(1.6)Tn→n→∞a.s.T  ⟺  P[{ω:Tn(ω)→n→∞T(ω)}]=1\tag{1.6} T_n \convas T \iff \P\left[\left\{\omega: T_n(\omega) \conv{} T(\omega)\right\} \right] = 1Tn​a.s.n→∞​T⟺P[{ω:Tn​(ω)n→∞​T(ω)}]=1(1.6)

Convergence in probability:

(1.7)Tn→n→∞PT  ⟺  ∀ε>0,P[∣Tn−T∣≥ε]→n→∞0\tag{1.7} T_n \convp T \iff \forall \varepsilon > 0, \P[|T_n - T| \geq \varepsilon] \conv{} 0Tn​Pn→∞​T⟺∀ε>0,P[∣Tn​−T∣≥ε]n→∞​0(1.7)

Convergence in distribution:

(1.8)Tn→n→∞(d)T  ⟺  E[f(Tn)]→n→∞E[f(T)]\tag{1.8} T_n \convd T \iff \E[f(T_n)] \conv{} \E[f(T)]Tn​(d)n→∞​T⟺E[f(Tn​)]n→∞​E[f(T)](1.8)

for all function fff continuous and bounded.

Convergence almost surely implies convergence in probability, which implies convergence in distribution.

If the limit has a density, then convergence in distribution implies convergence in probability.

Operations on convergence

Let (Tn)n,(Un)n(T_n)_n, (U_n)_n(Tn​)n​,(Un​)n​ but two sequences of random variables, and T,UT, UT,U be two random variables. If

Tn→n→∞a.s./PT,Un→n→∞a.s/PUT_n \conv{a.s./\P} T, U_n \conv{a.s/\P} UTn​a.s./Pn→∞​T,Un​a.s/Pn→∞​U

then:

(1.9)Tn+Un→n→∞a.s/PT+U\tag{1.9} T_n + U_n \conv{a.s/\P} T + UTn​+Un​a.s/Pn→∞​T+U(1.9)
(1.10)TnUn→n→∞a.s/PTU\tag{1.10} T_nU_n \conv{a.s/\P} TUTn​Un​a.s/Pn→∞​TU(1.10)

if in addition, U≠0U \neq 0U̸​=0 almost surely, then

(1.11)TnUn→n→∞a.s/PTU\tag{1.11} \frac{T_n}{U_n} \conv{a.s/\P} \frac{T}UUn​Tn​​a.s/Pn→∞​UT​(1.11)

Slutsky's Theorem. Let u∈Ru \in \Ru∈R. If

Tn→n→∞(d)T,Un→n→∞PuT_n \convd T, U_n \convp uTn​(d)n→∞​T,Un​Pn→∞​u

then:

(1.12)Tn+Un→n→∞(d)T+u\tag{1.12} T_n + U_n \convd T + uTn​+Un​(d)n→∞​T+u(1.12)
(1.13)TnUn→n→∞(d)uTn\tag{1.13} T_nU_n \convd uT_nTn​Un​(d)n→∞​uTn​(1.13)

if in addition, u≠0u \neq 0u̸​=0, then

(1.14)TnUn→n→∞(d)1uT\tag{1.14} \frac{T_n}{U_n} \convd \frac1uTUn​Tn​​(d)n→∞​u1​T(1.14)

Continuous mapping theorem. Let f∈C(R)f \in \mathcal{C}(\R)f∈C(R). If

Tn→n→∞a.s./P/(d)TT_n \conv{a.s./\P/(d)}TTn​a.s./P/(d)n→∞​T

then:

(1.15)f(Tn)→n→∞a.s./P/(d)f(T)\tag{1.15} f(T_n) \conv{a.s./\P/(d)} f(T)f(Tn​)a.s./P/(d)n→∞​f(T)(1.15)

Unit 2: Foundation of Inference

Lecture 3: Parametric Statistical Models

Trinity of statistical inference: estimation, confidence intervals and hypothesis testing.

Given X1,…,Xn∼i.i.dPX_1, \ldots, X_n \iid \PX1​,…,Xn​∼i.i.dP, the goal is to learn the distribution P\PP.

A statistical model is defined as:

(2.1)(E,(Pθ)θ∈Θ)\tag{2.1} \statmodel(E,(Pθ​)θ∈Θ​)(2.1)

where

  • EEE is the sample space,
  • (Pθ)θ∈Θ(\P_\theta)_{\theta \in \Theta}(Pθ​)θ∈Θ​ is a family of probability measures on EEE,
  • Θ\ThetaΘ is called the parameter set.

The model is well specified if

(2.2)∃θ∈Θ,Pθ=P\tag{2.2} \exists \theta \in \Theta, \P_\theta = \P∃θ∈Θ,Pθ​=P(2.2)

The model is called:

  • parametric if Θ⊆Rd\Theta \subseteq \R^dΘ⊆Rd for some d∈Nd \in \Nd∈N,
  • non-parametric if Θ\ThetaΘ is infinite-dimensional,
  • semi-parametric if Θ=Θ1×Θ2\Theta = \Theta_1 \times \Theta_2Θ=Θ1​×Θ2​ where Θ1⊆Rd\Theta_1 \subseteq \R^dΘ1​⊆Rd is the parameter set we are interested in, and Θ2\Theta_2Θ2​ is the nuisance parameter set.

The parameter θ\thetaθ is called identifiable if the mapping θ↦Pθ\theta \mapsto \P_\thetaθ↦Pθ​ is injective, i.e.:

(2.3)∀θ1,θ2∈Θ,θ1≠θ2  ⟹  Pθ1≠Pθ2\tag{2.3} \forall \theta_1, \theta_2 \in \Theta, \theta_1 \neq \theta_2 \implies \P_{\theta_1} \neq \P_{\theta_2}∀θ1​,θ2​∈Θ,θ1​̸​=θ2​⟹Pθ1​​̸​=Pθ2​​(2.3)

Lecture 4: Parametric Estimation and Confidence Intervals

A statistic is any measurable function of the sample.

An estimator of θ\thetaθ is any statistic whose expression doesn't depend on θ\thetaθ.

An estimator θ^n\thnθ^n​ of θ\thetaθ is weakly (resp. strongly) consistent if:

(2.4)θ^n→n→∞P  (resp.  a.s.)θ(Pθ)\tag{2.4} \thn \conv{\P\;(resp.\;a.s.)} \theta \quad (\P_\theta)θ^n​P(resp.a.s.)n→∞​θ(Pθ​)(2.4)

An estimator θ^n\thnθ^n​ of θ\thetaθ is asymptotically normal if:

(2.5)n(θ^n−θ)→n→∞(d)N(0,σ2)\tag{2.5} \sqrt{n}(\thn - \theta) \convd \Norm(0, \sigma^2)n​(θ^n​−θ)(d)n→∞​N(0,σ2)(2.5)

The quantity σ2\sigma^2σ2 is called the asymptotic variance of θ^n\thnθ^n​, noted

(2.6)V(θ^n)=σ2\tag{2.6} V(\thn) = \sigma^2V(θ^n​)=σ2(2.6)

The bias of an estimator θ^n\thnθ^n​ of θ\thetaθ is defined as:

(2.7)Bias⁡(θ^n)=E[θ^n]−θ\tag{2.7} \Bias(\thn) = \E[\thn] - \thetaBias(θ^n​)=E[θ^n​]−θ(2.7)

If Bias⁡(θ^n)=0\Bias(\thn) = 0Bias(θ^n​)=0, then we say that θ^n\thnθ^n​ is unbiased.

The quadratic risk (or risk) of an estimator θ^n\thnθ^n​ is

(2.8)R(θ^n)=E[(θ^n−θ)2]=V[θ^n]+Bias⁡(θ^n)2\tag{2.8} R(\thn) = \E\left[(\thn - \theta)^2\right] = \V[\thn] + \Bias(\thn)^2R(θ^n​)=E[(θ^n​−θ)2]=V[θ^n​]+Bias(θ^n​)2(2.8)

Let (E,(Pθ)θ∈Θ)\statmodel(E,(Pθ​)θ∈Θ​) be a statistical model with Θ⊆R\Theta \subseteq \RΘ⊆R associated with observations X1,…,XnX_1, \ldots, X_nX1​,…,Xn​, and α∈(0,1)\alpha \in (0, 1)α∈(0,1).

A confidence interval (C.I.) of level 1−α1 - \alpha1−α is any random interval I\mathcal{I}I independent from θ\thetaθ such as:

(2.9)∀θ∈Θ,Pθ[I∋θ]≥1−α\tag{2.9} \forall \theta \in \Theta, \P_\theta[\mathcal{I} \ni \theta] \geq 1 - \alpha∀θ∈Θ,Pθ​[I∋θ]≥1−α(2.9)

A C.I. of asymptotic level 1−α1 - \alpha1−α is any random interval In\mathcal{I}_nIn​ independent from θ\thetaθ such as:

(2.10)∀θ∈Θ,lim⁡n→∞Pθ[In∋θ]≥1−α\tag{2.10} \forall \theta \in \Theta, \limn\P_\theta[\mathcal{I}_n \ni \theta] \geq 1 - \alpha∀θ∈Θ,n→∞lim​Pθ​[In​∋θ]≥1−α(2.10)

Example: X1,…,Xn∼i.i.dBer(p)X_1, \ldots, X_n \iid \Ber(p)X1​,…,Xn​∼i.i.dBer(p). Our estimator is p^n=Xˉn\est{p} = \bar{X}_np^​n​=Xˉn​. From the CLT:

nXˉn−pp(1−p)→n→∞(d)N(0,1)\sqrt{n}\frac{\bar{X}_n - p}{\sqrt{p(1-p)}} \convd\Norm(0,1)n​p(1−p)​Xˉn​−p​(d)n→∞​N(0,1)

Therefore:

P[np(1−p)∣Xˉn−p∣≤qα/2]=1−α\P\left[\frac{\sqrt{n}}{\sqrt{p(1-p)}}|\bar{X}_n - p| \leq q_{\alpha/2}\right] = 1-\alpha P[p(1−p)​n​​∣Xˉn​−p∣≤qα/2​]=1−α
P[[Xˉn−p(1−p)nqα/2,Xˉn+p(1−p)nqα/2]∋p]=1−α\P\left[\left[\bar{X}_n - \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}}q_{\alpha/2}, \bar{X}_n + \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}}q_{\alpha/2}\right] \ni p\right] = 1-\alphaP[[Xˉn​−np(1−p)​​qα/2​,Xˉn​+np(1−p)​​qα/2​]∋p]=1−α

But this is not an asymptotic C.I. because the interval depends on ppp. We have three ways to find an actual confidence inteval:

Convervative bounds:

∀p∈(0,1),p(1−p)≤14  ⟹  Iconv=Xˉn+[−qα/22n,qα/22n]\forall p \in (0, 1), p(1-p) \leq \frac14 \implies \mathcal{I}_{conv} = \bar{X}_n + \left[-\frac{q_{\alpha/2}}{2\sqrt{n}}, \frac{q_{\alpha/2}}{2\sqrt{n}}\right]∀p∈(0,1),p(1−p)≤41​⟹Iconv​=Xˉn​+[−2n​qα/2​​,2n​qα/2​​]

Solve bounds, by solving the quadratic equation in ppp:

(p−Xˉn)2≤qα/22np(1−p)  ⟹  Isolve=[p1,p2](p - \bar{X}_n)^2 \leq \frac{q^2_{\alpha/2}}{n}p(1-p) \implies \mathcal{I}_{solve} = [p_1, p_2](p−Xˉn​)2≤nqα/22​​p(1−p)⟹Isolve​=[p1​,p2​]

Plug-in bounds; as p^n→n→∞a.s.p\est{p} \convas pp^​n​a.s.n→∞​p, we can apply Slutsky's theorem:

nXˉn−pp^n(1−p^n)→n→∞(d)N(0,1)  ⟹  Iplug=Xˉn+qα/2[−p^n(1−p^n)n,p^n(1−p^n)n]\sqrt{n}\frac{\bar{X}_n-p}{\sqrt{\est{p}(1 -\est{p})}} \convd \Norm(0, 1) \implies \mathcal{I}_{plug} = \bar{X}_n + q_{\alpha/2}\left[-\sqrt{\frac{\est{p}(1-\est{p})}{n}}, \sqrt{\frac{\est{p}(1-\est{p})}{n}}\right]n​p^​n​(1−p^​n​)​Xˉn​−p​(d)n→∞​N(0,1)⟹Iplug​=Xˉn​+qα/2​[−np^​n​(1−p^​n​)​​,np^​n​(1−p^​n​)​​]

All three intervals verify:

lim⁡n→∞P[I∋p]≥1−α\limn \P[\mathcal{I} \ni p] \geq 1 - \alphan→∞lim​P[I∋p]≥1−α

If I\mathcal{I}I is a confidence interval of level α\alphaα, it is also a confidence interval of level β\betaβ for all β≤α\beta \leq \alphaβ≤α.

A confidence interval of level α\alphaα means that if we repeat the experience multiple times, then the real parameter will be in the confidence interval with frequency α\alphaα. It does not mean that the real parameter is in the interval with a certain confidence (as the real parameter is deterministic).

Lecture 5: Delta Method and Confidence Intervals

The Delta Method. Let (Xn)n(X_n)_n(Xn​)n​ be a sequence of r.v. such as

n(Xn−θ)→n→∞(d)N(0,σ2)\sqrt{n}(X_n - \theta) \convd \Norm(0, \sigma^2)n​(Xn​−θ)(d)n→∞​N(0,σ2)

for some θ∈R,σ2>0\theta \in \R, \sigma^2 > 0θ∈R,σ2>0. Let g:R→Rg: \R \rightarrow \Rg:R→R continuously differentiable at θ\thetaθ. Then (g(Xn))n(g(X_n))_n(g(Xn​))n​ is asymptotically normal around g(θ)g(\theta)g(θ) and:

(2.11)n(g(Xn)−g(θ))→n→∞(d)N(0,g′(θ)2σ2)\tag{2.11}\sqrt{n}(g(X_n) - g(\theta)) \convd \Norm(0, g'(\theta)^2\sigma^2)n​(g(Xn​)−g(θ))(d)n→∞​N(0,g′(θ)2σ2)(2.11)

Lecture 6: Introduction to Hypothesis Testing, and Type 1 and Type 2 Errors

Let us consider a sample X1,…,XnX_1, \ldots, X_nX1​,…,Xn​ of i.i.d r.v. and a statistical model (E,(Pθ)θ∈Θ)\statmodel(E,(Pθ​)θ∈Θ​). Let us consider Θ0⨿Θ1=Θ\Theta_0 \amalg \Theta_1 = \ThetaΘ0​⨿Θ1​=Θ.

  • H0:θ∈Θ0H_0: \theta \in \Theta_0H0​:θ∈Θ0​ is called the null hypothesis,
  • H1:θ∈Θ1H_1: \theta \in \Theta_1H1​:θ∈Θ1​ is called the alternative hypothesis.

We are testing H0H_0H0​ against H1H_1H1​ to decide whether to reject H0H_0H0​ by looking for evidence against H0H_0H0​.

H0H_0H0​ and H1H_1H1​ do not play symmetric roles in hypothesis testing: H0H_0H0​ is the default hypothesis when we lack evidence.

A test is a statistic ψ:En→{0,1}\psi : E^n \rightarrow \{0, 1\}ψ:En→{0,1} such as:

  • If ψ(x1,…,xn)=0\psi(x_1, \ldots, x_n) = 0ψ(x1​,…,xn​)=0 then H0H_0H0​ is not rejected,
  • If ψ(x1,…,xn)=1\psi(x_1, \ldots, x_n) = 1ψ(x1​,…,xn​)=1 then H0H_0H0​ is rejected and H1H_1H1​ is accepted.

The rejection region of a test ψ\psiψ is:

(2.12)Rψ={x∈En,ψ(x)=1}\tag{2.12} R_\psi = \{\xx \in E^n, \psi(\xx) = 1\}Rψ​={x∈En,ψ(x)=1}(2.12)

The type 1 error of a test ψ\psiψ corresponds to rejecting H0H_0H0​ when it is actually true:

(2.13)αψ:Θ0→[0,1]θ↦Pθ[ψ(X)=1]\tag{2.13} \fun{\alpha_\psi}{\Theta_0}{[0, 1]}{\theta}{\P_\theta[\psi(\XX) = 1]}αψ​​:​Θ0​θ​→↦​[0,1]Pθ​[ψ(X)=1]​(2.13)

The type 2 error of a test ψ\psiψ corresponds to not rejecting H0H_0H0​ when H1H_1H1​ is actually true:

(2.14)βψ:Θ1→[0,1]θ↦Pθ[ψ(X)=0]\tag{2.14} \fun{\beta_\psi}{\Theta_1}{[0, 1]}{\theta}{\P_\theta[\psi(\XX) = 0]}βψ​​:​Θ1​θ​→↦​[0,1]Pθ​[ψ(X)=0]​(2.14)

Type 1 and type 2 errors are summaries as follows (RRR is real, TTT is test):

R\TH0H1H0✓1H12✓\begin{array}{ccc}R\char`\\ T & H_0 & H_1 \\ H_0 & \checkmark & 1 \\ H_1 & 2 & \checkmark \end{array}R\TH0​H1​​H0​✓2​H1​1✓​

The power of a test ψ\psiψ is:

(2.15)πψ=inf⁡θ∈Θ1(1−βψ(θ))\tag{2.15} \pi_\psi = \inf_{\theta \in \Theta_1}(1 - \beta_\psi(\theta))πψ​=θ∈Θ1​inf​(1−βψ​(θ))(2.15)

Lecture 7: Hypothesis Testing (Continued): Levels and P-values

A test ψ\psiψ has level α\alphaα if:

(2.16)∀θ∈Θ0,αψ(θ)≤α\tag{2.16} \forall \theta \in \Theta_0, \alpha_\psi(\theta) \leq \alpha∀θ∈Θ0​,αψ​(θ)≤α(2.16)

A test ψ\psiψ has asymptotic level α\alphaα if:

(2.17)∀θ∈Θ0,lim⁡n→∞αψn(θ)≤α\tag{2.17} \forall \theta \in \Theta_0, \limn \alpha_{\psi_n}(\theta) \leq \alpha∀θ∈Θ0​,n→∞lim​αψn​​(θ)≤α(2.17)

In general, a test has the form

ψ=1{Tn>c}\psi = \one\{T_n > c\}ψ=1{Tn​>c}

for some statistic TnT_nTn​ and threshold ccc. TnT_nTn​ is called the test statistic and the rejection region is Rψ={Tn>c}R_\psi = \{T_n > c\}Rψ​={Tn​>c}.

We have two main types of tests:

  • If H0:θ=θ0H_0: \theta = \theta_0H0​:θ=θ0​ and H1:θ≠θ0H_1: \theta \neq \theta_0H1​:θ̸​=θ0​, it is a two-sided test,
  • If H0:θ≤θ0H_0: \theta \leq \theta_0H0​:θ≤θ0​ and H1:θ>θ0H_1: \theta > \theta_0H1​:θ>θ0​, it is a one-sided test.

Example: Let X1,…,Xn∼i.i.dD(μ)X_1, …, X_n \iid \mathcal{D}(\mu)X1​,…,Xn​∼i.i.dD(μ) where μ\muμ and σ2\sigma^2σ2 are the expectation and variance of D(μ)\mathcal{D}(\mu)D(μ). Let's consider μ0\mu_0μ0​.

We want to test H0:μ=μ0H_0: \mu = \mu_0H0​:μ=μ0​ against H1:μ≠μ0H_1: \mu \neq \mu_0H1​:μ̸​=μ0​ with asymptotic level α\alphaα.

(2.18)Tn=nμ^n−μ0σ→n→∞(d)N(0,1)\tag{2.18} T_n = \sqrt{n}\frac{\est{\mu} - \mu_0}{\sigma} \convd \Norm(0, 1)Tn​=n​σμ^​n​−μ0​​(d)n→∞​N(0,1)(2.18)

Therefore, if H0H_0H0​ is true, then

P[∣Tn∣>qα/2]→n→∞α\P[|T_n| > q_{\alpha/2}] \conv{} \alphaP[∣Tn​∣>qα/2​]n→∞​α

Let ψα=1{∣Tn∣>qα/2}\psi_\alpha = \one\{|T_n| > q_{\alpha/2}\}ψα​=1{∣Tn​∣>qα/2​}.

Now, we want to test H0:μ≤μ0H_0: \mu \leq \mu_0H0​:μ≤μ0​ and H1:μ>μ0H_1: \mu > \mu_0H1​:μ>μ0​ with asymptotic level α\alphaα. Which value of μ∈Θ0\mu \in \Theta_0μ∈Θ0​ should we consider?

Type 1 error is the function μ↦Pμ[ψ(X)=1]\mu \mapsto \P_\mu[\psi(\XX) = 1]μ↦Pμ​[ψ(X)=1]. To control the level, we need the μ\muμ that maximises this expression over Θ0\Theta_0Θ0​: clearly, this happens for μ=μ0\mu = \mu_0μ=μ0​. Therefore, if H0H_0H0​ is true, then

Pμ0[Tn>qα]→n→∞α\P_{\mu_0}[T_n > q_\alpha] \conv{} \alphaPμ0​​[Tn​>qα​]n→∞​α

If H1:μ<μ0H_1: \mu < \mu_0H1​:μ<μ0​, then we want Pμ0[Tn<−qα]\P_{\mu_0}[T_n < -q_\alpha]Pμ0​​[Tn​<−qα​].

The (asymptotic) p-value of a test ψα\psi_\alphaψα​ is the smallest (asymptotic) level α\alphaα at which ψα\psi_\alphaψα​ rejects H0H_0H0​. The p-value is random and depends on the sample.

The golden rule: H0H_0H0​ is rejected by ψα\psi_\alphaψα​ at any asymptotic level α≥p-value⁡(X)\alpha \geq \pval(\XX)α≥p-value(X).

Unit 3: Methods of estimation

Lecture 8: Distance measures between distributions

Let (E,(Pθ)θ∈Θ)\statmodel(E,(Pθ​)θ∈Θ​) a statistical model, associated with a sample of i.i.d r.v. X1,…,XnX_1, \ldots, X_nX1​,…,Xn​. We assume the model is well specified, i.e. ∃θ∗∈Θ,X∼Pθ∗\exists \tth \in \Theta, X \sim \P_\tth∃θ∗∈Θ,X∼Pθ∗​. θ∗\tthθ∗ is called the true parameter.

We want to find an estimator θ^n\thnθ^n​ such that Pθ^n\P_{\thn}Pθ^n​​ is close to Pθ∗\P_\tthPθ∗​.

The total variation distance between two probability measures P1\P_1P1​ and P2\P_2P2​ is defined as:

(3.1)TV⁡(P1,P2)=max⁡A⊂E∣P1(A)−P2(A)∣\tag{3.1} \TV(\P_1, \P_2) = \max_{A \subset E}|\P_1(A) - \P_2(A)|TV(P1​,P2​)=A⊂Emax​∣P1​(A)−P2​(A)∣(3.1)

If EEE is discrete, and p1,p2p_1, p_2p1​,p2​ are the PMF associated with P1\P_1P1​ and P2\P_2P2​:

(3.2)TV⁡(P1,P2)=12∑x∈E∣p1(x)−p2(x)∣\tag{3.2} \TV(\P_1, \P_2) = \frac12\sum_{x\in E}|p_1(x) - p_2(x)|TV(P1​,P2​)=21​x∈E∑​∣p1​(x)−p2​(x)∣(3.2)

If EEE is continuous, and f1,f2f_1, f_2f1​,f2​ are the PDF associated with P1\P_1P1​ and P2\P_2P2​:

(3.3)TV⁡(P1,P2)=12∫E∣f1(x)−f2(x)∣dx\tag{3.3} \TV(\P_1, \P_2) = \frac12\int_E|f_1(x) - f_2(x)|dxTV(P1​,P2​)=21​∫E​∣f1​(x)−f2​(x)∣dx(3.3)

Proprieties of the total variation distance:

  • The TV⁡\TVTV is symmetric: ∀P1,P2,TV⁡(P1,P2)=TV⁡(P2,P1)\forall \P_1, \P_2, \TV(\P_1, \P_2) = \TV(\P_2, \P_1)∀P1​,P2​,TV(P1​,P2​)=TV(P2​,P1​)
  • The TV⁡\TVTV is positive: ∀P1,P2,0≤TV⁡(P1,P2)≤1\forall \P_1, \P_2, 0 \leq \TV(\P_1, \P_2) \leq 1∀P1​,P2​,0≤TV(P1​,P2​)≤1
  • The TV⁡\TVTV is definite: ∀P1,P2,TV⁡(P1,P2)=0  ⟹  P1=P2\forall \P_1, \P_2, \TV(\P_1, \P_2) = 0 \implies \P_1 = \P_2∀P1​,P2​,TV(P1​,P2​)=0⟹P1​=P2​ p.p.
  • The TV⁡\TVTV verifies the triangle inequality: ∀P1,P2,P3,TV⁡(P1,P3)≤TV⁡(P1,P2)+TV⁡(P2,P3)\forall \P_1, \P_2, \P_3, \TV(\P_1, \P_3) \leq \TV(\P_1, \P_2) + \TV(\P_2, \P_3)∀P1​,P2​,P3​,TV(P1​,P3​)≤TV(P1​,P2​)+TV(P2​,P3​)

Therefore, TV⁡\TVTV is a distance between probability distributions.

Problem 1: TV⁡\TVTV cannot compare discrete and continuous distributions, which means we cannot trust it to give a reliable estimation of distance between unrelated distributions.

Problem 2: We cannot build an estimator θ↦TV⁡^(Pθ,Pθ∗)\theta \mapsto \widehat{\TV}(\P_\theta, \P_\tth)θ↦TV(Pθ​,Pθ∗​) as we do not know θ∗\tthθ∗.

Hence we need another "distance" between distributions. The Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence between two probability distributions P1,P2\P_1, \P_2P1​,P2​ is defined as:

(3.4)KL⁡(P1,P2)={∑x∈Ep1(x)ln⁡p1(x)p2(x)if E is discrete∫Ef1(x)ln⁡f1(x)f2(x)dxif E is continuous\tag{3.4} \KL(\P_1, \P_2)= \begin{cases}\displaystyle\sum_{x\in E}p_1(x)\ln\frac{p_1(x)}{p_2(x)} & \text{if }E\text{ is discrete} \\ \displaystyle \int_Ef_1(x)\ln\frac{f_1(x)}{f_2(x)}dx & \text{if }E\text{ is continuous}\end{cases}KL(P1​,P2​)=⎩⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎧​x∈E∑​p1​(x)lnp2​(x)p1​(x)​∫E​f1​(x)lnf2​(x)f1​(x)​dx​if E is discreteif E is continuous​(3.4)

Proprieties of the KL⁡\KLKL divergence:

  • In general, KL⁡(P1,P2)≠KL⁡(P2,P1)\KL(\P_1, \P_2) \neq \KL(\P_2, \P_1)KL(P1​,P2​)̸​=KL(P2​,P1​)
  • The KL⁡\KLKL is positive: ∀P1,P2,KL⁡(P1,P2)≥0\forall \P_1, \P_2, \KL(\P_1, \P_2) \geq 0∀P1​,P2​,KL(P1​,P2​)≥0
  • The KL⁡\KLKL is definite: ∀P1,P2,KL⁡(P1,P2)=0  ⟹  P1=P2\forall \P_1, \P_2, \KL(\P_1, \P_2) = 0 \implies \P_1 = \P_2∀P1​,P2​,KL(P1​,P2​)=0⟹P1​=P2​
  • In general, KL⁡(P1,P3)̸≤KL⁡(P1,P2)+KL⁡(P2,P3)\KL(\P_1, \P_3) \not\leq \KL(\P_1, \P_2) + \KL(\P_2, \P_3)KL(P1​,P3​)̸​≤KL(P1​,P2​)+KL(P2​,P3​)

KL⁡\KLKL is not a distance, it's a divergence. But we still have that θ∗\tthθ∗ is the only minimizer of θ↦KL⁡(Pθ∗,Pθ)\theta \mapsto \KL(\P_\tth, \P_\theta)θ↦KL(Pθ∗​,Pθ​).

Lecture 9: Maximum Likelihood Estimation

KL⁡(Pθ∗,Pθ)=Eθ∗[ln⁡fθ∗(X)fθ(X)]=Eθ∗[ln⁡fθ∗(X)]−Eθ∗[ln⁡fθ(X)]\begin{aligned}\KL(\P_\tth, \P_\theta) &= \E_\tth\left[\ln\frac{f_\tth(X)}{f_\theta(X)}\right] \\ &= \E_\tth[\ln f_\tth(X)] - \E_\tth[\ln f_\theta(X)]\end{aligned}KL(Pθ∗​,Pθ​)​=Eθ∗​[lnfθ​(X)fθ∗​(X)​]=Eθ∗​[lnfθ∗​(X)]−Eθ∗​[lnfθ​(X)]​

Therefore, by the LLN the KL⁡\KLKL divergence can be estimated by taking the average of ln⁡fθ(Xi)\ln f_\theta(X_i)lnfθ​(Xi​):

KL⁡^(Pθ∗,Pθ)=constant−1n∑i=1nln⁡fθ(Xi)\widehat{\KL}(\P_\tth, \P_\theta) = \text{constant} - \frac1n\sum_{i=1}^n\ln f_\theta(X_i)KL(Pθ∗​,Pθ​)=constant−n1​i=1∑n​lnfθ​(Xi​)

Therefore:

argmin⁡θ∈ΘKL⁡^(Pθ∗,Pθ)=argmin⁡θ∈Θ−1n∑i=1nln⁡fθ(Xi)=argmax⁡θ∈Θln⁡∏i=1nfθ(Xi)=argmax⁡θ∈Θ∏i=1nfθ(Xi)\begin{aligned} \argmin{\theta \in \Theta}\widehat{\KL}(\P_\tth, \P_\theta) &= \argmin{\theta \in \Theta} -\frac1n\sum_{i=1}^n\ln f_\theta(X_i) \\ &= \argmax{\theta \in \Theta}\ln\prod_{i=1}^nf_\theta(X_i) \\ &= \argmax{\theta \in \Theta}\prod_{i=1}^nf_\theta(X_i) \end{aligned}θ∈Θargmin​KL(Pθ∗​,Pθ​)​=θ∈Θargmin​−n1​i=1∑n​lnfθ​(Xi​)=θ∈Θargmax​lni=1∏n​fθ​(Xi​)=θ∈Θargmax​i=1∏n​fθ​(Xi​)​

This is the maximum likelihood principle.

Let (E,(Pθ)θ∈Θ)\statmodel(E,(Pθ​)θ∈Θ​) be a statistical model associated with a sample of i.i.d r.v. X1,…,XnX_1, \ldots, X_nX1​,…,Xn​. The likelihood of the model is the function:

(3.5)Ln:En×Θ→[0,1](x1,…,xn,θ)↦{∏i=1npθ(xi)if E is discrete∏i=1nfθ(xi)if E is continous\tag{3.5}\fun{L_n}{E^n \times \Theta}{[0, 1]}{(x_1, \ldots, x_n, \theta)}{\begin{cases} \displaystyle \prod_{i=1}^np_\theta(x_i) & \text{if }E\text{ is discrete} \\ \displaystyle \prod_{i=1}^nf_\theta(x_i) & \text{if }E\text{ is continous} \end{cases}}Ln​​:​En×Θ(x1​,…,xn​,θ)​→↦​[0,1]⎩⎪⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎪⎧​i=1∏n​pθ​(xi​)i=1∏n​fθ​(xi​)​if E is discreteif E is continous​​(3.5)

The maximum likelihood estimator of θ\thetaθ is defined as:

(3.6)θ^nMLE=argmax⁡θ∈ΘLn(X1,…,Xn,θ)\tag{3.6} \thn^{MLE} = \argmax{\theta \in \Theta} L_n(X_1, \ldots, X_n, \theta)θ^nMLE​=θ∈Θargmax​Ln​(X1​,…,Xn​,θ)(3.6)

In practice, we often use the log-likelihood ℓn(x1,…,xn,θ)=ln⁡Ln(x1,…,xn,θ)\ell_n(x_1, \ldots, x_n, \theta) = \ln L_n(x_1, \ldots, x_n, \theta)ℓn​(x1​,…,xn​,θ)=lnLn​(x1​,…,xn​,θ).

A function twice differentiable h:Θ⊆R→Rh : \Theta \subseteq \R \rightarrow \Rh:Θ⊆R→R is concave (resp. strictly) if

(3.7)∀θ∈Θ,h′′(θ)≤0(resp. <0)\tag{3.7} \forall \theta \in \Theta, h''(\theta) \leq 0 \quad\text{(resp. }< 0\text{)}∀θ∈Θ,h′′(θ)≤0(resp. <0)(3.7)

hhh is convex (resp. strictly) if −h-h−h is concave (resp. strictly).

A con-v-ex function is shaped like a v.

Let h:Θ⊆Rd→Rh: \Theta \subseteq \R^d \rightarrow \Rh:Θ⊆Rd→R be a multivariate function. The gradient vector of hhh is:

(3.8)∇h(θ)=(∂h∂θ1(θ)⋮∂h∂θd(θ))\tag{3.8} \nabla h(\ttheta) = \begin{pmatrix}\displaystyle \diff{h}{\theta_1}(\ttheta) \\ \displaystyle \vdots \\ \displaystyle \diff{h}{\theta_d}(\ttheta)\end{pmatrix}∇h(θ)=⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​∂θ1​∂h​(θ)⋮∂θd​∂h​(θ)​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​(3.8)

The Hessian matrix of hhh is:

(3.9)Hh(θ)=(∂2h∂θ12(θ)⋯∂2h∂θ1∂θd(θ)⋮⋱⋮∂2h∂θd∂θ1(θ)⋯∂2h∂θd2(θ))∈Rd×d\tag{3.9} \HH h(\ttheta) = \begin{pmatrix} \displaystyle \diffk{h}{\theta_1}{2}(\ttheta) & \cdots & \displaystyle \diffd{h}{\theta_1}{\theta_d}(\ttheta) \\ \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ \displaystyle \diffd{h}{\theta_d}{\theta_1}(\ttheta) & \cdots & \displaystyle \diffk{h}{\theta_d}{2}(\ttheta) \\ \end{pmatrix} \in \R^{d\times d}Hh(θ)=⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​∂θ12​∂2h​(θ)⋮∂θd​∂θ1​∂2h​(θ)​⋯⋱⋯​∂θ1​∂θd​∂2h​(θ)⋮∂θd2​∂2h​(θ)​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​∈Rd×d(3.9)

Therefore, hhh is concave (resp. strictly) if

(3.10)∀x∈Rd∖{0},θ∈Θ,xTHh(θ)x≤0(resp. <0)\tag{3.10} \forall \xx \in \R^d \setminus \{\zz\}, \ttheta \in \Theta, \xx^T\HH h(\ttheta)\xx \leq 0 \quad\text{(resp. }< 0\text{)}∀x∈Rd∖{0},θ∈Θ,xTHh(θ)x≤0(resp. <0)(3.10)

If hhh is strictly concave and has a maximum, then this maximum is unique and is reached for

(3.11){h′(θ)=0if Θ⊆R∇h(θ)=0if Θ⊆Rd\tag{3.11} \begin{cases} h'(\theta) = 0 & \text{if }\Theta \subseteq \R \\ \nabla h(\ttheta) = \zz & \text{if }\Theta \subseteq \R^d \end{cases}{h′(θ)=0∇h(θ)=0​if Θ⊆Rif Θ⊆Rd​(3.11)

Lecture 10: Consistency of MLE, Covariance Matrices, and Multivariate Statistics

Under mild regularity conditions, we have

(3.12)θ^nMLE→n→∞Pθ∗\tag{3.12} \thn^{MLE} \convp \tthθ^nMLE​Pn→∞​θ∗(3.12)

Notably if the model is well specified.

In general, when θ∈Rd\theta \in \R^dθ∈Rd, the coordinates are not independent. The covariance between two random variables XXX and YYY is defined as:

(3.13)Cov⁡(X,Y)=E[(X−E[X])(Y−E[Y])]=E[XY]−E[X]E[Y]=E[X(Y−E[Y])]\tag{3.13} \begin{aligned} \Cov(X, Y) &= \E[(X - \E[X])(Y - \E[Y])] \\ &= \E[XY] - \E[X]\E[Y] \\ &= \E[X(Y - \E[Y])] \end{aligned}Cov(X,Y)​=E[(X−E[X])(Y−E[Y])]=E[XY]−E[X]E[Y]=E[X(Y−E[Y])]​(3.13)

Properties:

(3.14)Cov⁡(X,X)=V(X)\tag{3.14} \Cov(X, X) = \V(X)Cov(X,X)=V(X)(3.14)
(3.15)Cov⁡(X,Y)=Cov⁡(Y,X)\tag{3.15} \Cov(X, Y) = \Cov(Y, X)Cov(X,Y)=Cov(Y,X)(3.15)

If XXX and YYY are independent, then Cov⁡(X,Y)=0\Cov(X, Y) = 0Cov(X,Y)=0 and E[XY]=E[X]E[Y]\E[XY] = \E[X]\E[Y]E[XY]=E[X]E[Y].

Attention: the converse is not true; if Cov⁡(X,Y)=0\Cov(X, Y) = 0Cov(X,Y)=0, XXX and YYY may be dependent.

If X=(X(1),…,X(d))T∈Rd\XX = (X^{(1)}, \ldots, X^{(d)})^T \in \R^dX=(X(1),…,X(d))T∈Rd, then the covariance matrix of the vector is given by:

(3.16)Σ=Cov⁡(X)=E[(X−E[X])(X−E[X])T]∈Rd×d\tag{3.16} \SSigma = \CCov(\XX) = \E[(\XX - \E[\XX])(\XX - \E[\XX])^T] \in \R^{d \times d}Σ=Cov(X)=E[(X−E[X])(X−E[X])T]∈Rd×d(3.16)

Its terms are:

Σi,j=Cov⁡(X(i),X(j))\SSigma_{i,j} = \Cov(X^{(i)}, X^{(j)})Σi,j​=Cov(X(i),X(j))

Proprieties:

(3.17)Cov⁡(AX+B)=Cov⁡(AX)=ACov⁡(X)AT\tag{3.17} \CCov(A\XX + B) = \CCov(A\XX) = A\CCov(\XX)A^TCov(AX+B)=Cov(AX)=ACov(X)AT(3.17)

The Multivariate Central Limit Theorem, let X1,…,Xn∈Rd\XX_1, \ldots, \XX_n \in \R^dX1​,…,Xn​∈Rd i.i.d copies of X\XXX such that E[X]=μ\E[\XX] = \mmuE[X]=μ and Cov⁡(X)=Σ\CCov(\XX) = \SSigmaCov(X)=Σ. Then:

(3.18)n(Xˉn−μ)→n→∞(d)Nd(0,Σ)\tag{3.18} \sqrt{n}(\bar{\XX}_n - \mmu) \convd \Norm_d(\zz, \SSigma)n​(Xˉn​−μ)(d)n→∞​Nd​(0,Σ)(3.18)

Equivalently,

nΣ−1/2(Xˉn−μ)→n→∞(d)Nd(0,Id)\sqrt{n}\SSigma^{-1/2}(\bar{\XX}_n - \mmu) \convd \Norm_d(\zz, I_d)n​Σ−1/2(Xˉn​−μ)(d)n→∞​Nd​(0,Id​)

The Multivariate Delta Method, let (Tn)n∈(Rd)N(\TT_n)_n \in (\R^d)^\N(Tn​)n​∈(Rd)N be a sequence of random vectors such that

n(Tn−θ)→n→∞(d)Nd(0,Σ)\sqrt{n}(\TT_n - \ttheta) \convd \Norm_d(\zz, \SSigma)n​(Tn​−θ)(d)n→∞​Nd​(0,Σ)

with θ∈Rd,Σ∈Rd×d\ttheta \in \R^d, \SSigma \in \R^{d\times d}θ∈Rd,Σ∈Rd×d. Let g:Rd→Rk\bm{g}: \R^d \rightarrow \R^kg:Rd→Rk be continuously differentiable in θ\tthetaθ. Then:

(3.19)n(g(Tn)−g(θ))→n→∞(d)Nk(0,∇g(θ)TΣ∇g(θ))\tag{3.19} \sqrt{n}(\bm{g}(\TT_n) - \bm{g}(\ttheta)) \convd \Norm_k(\zz, \nabla \bm{g}(\ttheta)^T\SSigma\nabla \bm{g}(\ttheta))n​(g(Tn​)−g(θ))(d)n→∞​Nk​(0,∇g(θ)TΣ∇g(θ))(3.19)

where

∇g(θ)=(∂gj∂θi)i,j=(∇g1(θ),⋯ ,∇gk(θ))\nabla \bm{g}(\ttheta) = \left(\diff{g_j}{\theta_i}\right)_{i, j} = \left(\nabla g_1(\ttheta), \cdots,\nabla g_k(\ttheta)\right)∇g(θ)=(∂θi​∂gj​​)i,j​=(∇g1​(θ),⋯,∇gk​(θ))

Lecture 11: Fisher Information, Asymptotic Normality of MLE; Methods of Moments

Let (E,(Pθ)θ∈Θ)\statmodel(E,(Pθ​)θ∈Θ​) be a statistical model with Θ⊆Rd\Theta \subseteq \R^dΘ⊆Rd, and X\XXX an associated random variable. With

ℓ(θ)=ln⁡L1(X,θ)\ell(\ttheta) = \ln L_1(\XX, \ttheta)ℓ(θ)=lnL1​(X,θ)

The Fisher Information of the model is defined as:

(3.20)I:θ↦E[∇ℓ(θ)∇ℓ(θ)T]−E[∇ℓ(θ)]E[∇ℓ(θ)]T\tag{3.20} I : \ttheta \mapsto \E[\nabla\ell(\ttheta)\nabla\ell(\ttheta)^T] - \E[\nabla\ell(\ttheta)]\E[\nabla\ell(\ttheta)]^TI:θ↦E[∇ℓ(θ)∇ℓ(θ)T]−E[∇ℓ(θ)]E[∇ℓ(θ)]T(3.20)

Under some regularity conditions, we have that:

(3.21)I(θ)=−E[Hℓ(θ)]\tag{3.21} I(\ttheta) = - \E[\HH\ell(\ttheta)]I(θ)=−E[Hℓ(θ)](3.21)

If Θ⊆R\Theta \subseteq \RΘ⊆R, we have:

(3.22)I(θ)=V[ℓ′(θ)]=−E[ℓ′′(θ)]\tag{3.22} I(\theta) = \V[\ell'(\theta)] = -\E[\ell''(\theta)]I(θ)=V[ℓ′(θ)]=−E[ℓ′′(θ)](3.22)

Asymptotic normality of the MLE. Let θ∗∈Θ\ttth \in \Thetaθ∗∈Θ be the true parameter. If we have the following:

  • θ∗\ttthθ∗ is identifiable,
  • ∀θ∈Θ\forall \ttheta \in \Theta∀θ∈Θ, the support of Pθ\P_\thetaPθ​ does not depend on θ\thetaθ,
  • θ∗\ttthθ∗ is not on the boundary of Θ\ThetaΘ,
  • I(θ)I(\ttheta)I(θ) is invertible in a neighborhood of θ∗\ttthθ∗,
  • A few more technical conditions,

then θ^nMLE\tthn^{MLE}θ^nMLE​ satisfies:

(3.23)θ^nMLE→n→∞Pθ∗[Pθ∗]\tag{3.23} \tthn^{MLE} \convp \ttth \quad [\P_{\ttth}]θ^nMLE​Pn→∞​θ∗[Pθ∗​](3.23)
(3.24)n(θ^nMLE−θ∗)→n→∞(d)Nd(0,I(θ∗)−1)[Pθ∗]\tag{3.24} \sqrt{n}(\tthn^{MLE} - \ttth) \convd \Norm_d(0, I(\ttth)^{-1}) \quad [\P_{\ttth}]n​(θ^nMLE​−θ∗)(d)n→∞​Nd​(0,I(θ∗)−1)[Pθ∗​](3.24)

Let X1,…,Xn\XX_1, …, \XX_nX1​,…,Xn​ be an i.i.d sample associated with a statistical model (E,(Pθ)θ∈Θ)\statmodel(E,(Pθ​)θ∈Θ​), with E⊆RE \subseteq \RE⊆R and Θ⊆Rd\Theta \subseteq \R^dΘ⊆Rd. The population moments are:

(3.25)∀1≤k≤d,mk(θ)=Eθ[Xk]\tag{3.25} \forall 1 \leq k \leq d, m_k(\ttheta) = \E_\ttheta[X^k]∀1≤k≤d,mk​(θ)=Eθ​[Xk](3.25)

And the empirical moments are:

(3.26)∀1≤k≤d,m^k=Xnk‾=1n∑i=1nXik\tag{3.26} \forall 1 \leq k \leq d, \hat{m}_k = \overline{X^k_n} = \frac1n\sum_{i=1}^nX_i^k∀1≤k≤d,m^k​=Xnk​​=n1​i=1∑n​Xik​(3.26)

From the LLN, we have

(3.27)(m^1,…,m^d)→n→∞P/a.s.(m1(θ),…,md(θ))\tag{3.27} (\hat{m}_1, \ldots, \hat{m}_d) \conv{\P / a.s.} (m_1(\ttheta), \ldots, m_d(\ttheta))(m^1​,…,m^d​)P/a.s.n→∞​(m1​(θ),…,md​(θ))(3.27)

Let

M:Θ→Rdθ↦M(θ)=(m1(θ),…,nd(θ))\fun{M}{\Theta}{\R^d}{\ttheta}{M(\ttheta) = (m_1(\ttheta), \ldots, n_d(\ttheta))}M​:​Θθ​→↦​RdM(θ)=(m1​(θ),…,nd​(θ))​

Then if MMM is injective, θ=M−1(m1(θ),…,md(θ))\ttheta = M^{-1}(m_1(\ttheta), \ldots, m_d(\ttheta))θ=M−1(m1​(θ),…,md​(θ))

The moment estimator of θ\tthetaθ, if it exists, is defined as

(3.28)θ^nMM=M−1(m^1,…,m^d)\tag{3.28} \tthn^{MM} = M^{-1}(\hat m_1, \ldots, \hat m_d)θ^nMM​=M−1(m^1​,…,m^d​)(3.28)

Let M^=(m^1,…,m^d)\hat M = (\hat m_1, \ldots, \hat m_d)M^=(m^1​,…,m^d​). Let Σ(θ)=Cov⁡θ(X,X2,…,Xd)\SSigma(\ttheta) = \CCov_\ttheta(X, X^2, \ldots, X^d)Σ(θ)=Covθ​(X,X2,…,Xd). Let us assume M−1M^{-1}M−1 is continuously differentiable at M(θ)M(\ttheta)M(θ).

We can generalize the method of moments to any set of functions g1,…,gd:R→Rg_1, \ldots, g_d : R \rightarrow \Rg1​,…,gd​:R→R well chosen, by defining mk(θ)=Eθ[gk(X)]m_k(\ttheta) = \E_\ttheta[g_k(X)]mk​(θ)=Eθ​[gk​(X)] and Σ(θ)=Cov⁡θ(g1(X),…,gk(X))\SSigma(\ttheta) = \CCov_\ttheta(g_1(X), \ldots, g_k(X))Σ(θ)=Covθ​(g1​(X),…,gk​(X)).

The generalized method of moments yields, by applying the CLT and the Delta method:

(3.29)n(θ^nMM−θ)→n→∞(d)Nd(0,Γ(θ))\tag{3.29} \sqrt{n}(\tthn^{MM} - \theta) \convd\Norm_d(\zz, \Gamma(\ttheta))n​(θ^nMM​−θ)(d)n→∞​Nd​(0,Γ(θ))(3.29)

where

Γ(θ)=[∇M−1(M(θ))]TΣ(θ)[∇M−1(M(θ))]\Gamma(\ttheta) = \left[\nabla M^{-1}(M(\ttheta))\right]^T\SSigma(\ttheta)\left[\nabla M^{-1}(M(\ttheta))\right]Γ(θ)=[∇M−1(M(θ))]TΣ(θ)[∇M−1(M(θ))]

The MLEMLEMLE is more accurate than the MMMMMM, the MLEMLEMLE still gives good results if the model is mis-specified, however the MMMMMM is easier to compute and the MLEMLEMLE can be intractable sometimes.

Lecture 12: M-Estimation

Let X1,…,Xn∼i.i.dPX_1, \ldots, X_n \iid \PX1​,…,Xn​∼i.i.dP on a sample space E⊆RdE \subseteq \R^dE⊆Rd.

The goal is to estimate some parameter μ∗\true\mmuμ∗ associated with P\PP. We find a function ρ:E×M→R\rho : E \times \mathcal{M} \rightarrow \Rρ:E×M→R, where M\mathcal{M}M is the parameter set for μ∗\true\mmuμ∗, such that:

Q(μ)=E[ρ(X,μ)]\mathcal{Q}(\mmu) = \E[\rho(\XX, \mmu)]Q(μ)=E[ρ(X,μ)]

verifies

(3.30)μ∗=argmin⁡μ∈MQ(μ)\tag{3.30} \true\mu = \argmin{\mu \in \mathcal{M}}\mathcal{Q}(\mu)μ∗=μ∈Margmin​Q(μ)(3.30)

For example:

  • if ρ(x,μ)=∥x−μ∥22\rho(\xx, \mmu) = \|\xx - \mmu\|_2^2ρ(x,μ)=∥x−μ∥22​, then μ∗=E[X]\true\mmu = \E[\XX]μ∗=E[X].
  • if ρ(x,μ)=∣x−μ∣\rho(x, \mu) = |x - \mu|ρ(x,μ)=∣x−μ∣, then μ∗=Med⁡(X)\true\mu = \Med{}(X)μ∗=Med​(X).

Let α∈(0,1)\alpha \in (0, 1)α∈(0,1). We define the check functions:

Cα:R→Rx↦{−(1−α)xif x<0αxif x≥0\fun{C_\alpha}{\R}{\R}{x}{\begin{cases} -(1-\alpha)x & \text{if } x < 0 \\ \alpha x & \text{if } x \geq 0 \end{cases}}Cα​​:​Rx​→↦​R{−(1−α)xαx​if x<0if x≥0​​

If (E,(Pθ)θ∈Θ)\statmodel(E,(Pθ​)θ∈Θ​) is a statistical model associated with the data, M=Θ\mathcal{M} = \ThetaM=Θ, and ρ=−ℓ1\rho = -\ell_1ρ=−ℓ1​ the negative log-likelihood, then

(3.31)μ∗=θ∗\tag{3.31}\true\mmu = \ttthμ∗=θ∗(3.31)

where P=Pθ∗\P = \P_\ttthP=Pθ∗​. As such, the MLEMLEMLE estimator is an M-estimator.

Let

J(μ)=HQ(μ)J(\mmu) = \HH Q(\mmu)J(μ)=HQ(μ)

under some regularity conditions,

J(μ)=E[∂2ρ∂μ∂μT(X,μ)]J(\mmu) = \E\left[\diffd{\rho}{\mmu}{\mmu^T}(X, \mmu)\right]J(μ)=E[∂μ∂μT∂2ρ​(X,μ)]

Let

K(μ)=Cov⁡[∇μρ(X,μ)]K(\mmu) = \CCov\left[\nabla_\mmu\rho(X, \mmu)\right]K(μ)=Cov[∇μ​ρ(X,μ)]

In the case of the log-likelihood, we have J(θ)=K(θ)=I(θ)J(\ttheta) = K(\ttheta) = I(\ttheta)J(θ)=K(θ)=I(θ).

Let μ∗∈M\true\mmu \in \mathcal{M}μ∗∈M be the true parameter. If we have:

  • μ∗\true\mmuμ∗ is the only minimizer of Q\mathcal{Q}Q,
  • J(μ)J(\mmu)J(μ) is invertible for all μ∈M\mmu \in \mathcal{M}μ∈M,
  • A few more technical conditions,

then μ^n\est{\mmu}μ^​n​ satisfies:

(3.32)μ^n→n→∞Pμ∗\tag{3.32} \est{\mmu} \convp \true\mmuμ^​n​Pn→∞​μ∗(3.32)
(3.33)n(μ^n−μ∗)→n→∞(d)Nd(0,J−1(μ∗)TK(μ∗)J−1(μ∗))\tag{3.33} \sqrt{n}(\est{\mmu} - \true\mmu) \convd \Norm_d(\zz, J^{-1}(\true\mmu)^TK(\true\mmu)J^{-1}(\true\mmu))n​(μ^​n​−μ∗)(d)n→∞​Nd​(0,J−1(μ∗)TK(μ∗)J−1(μ∗))(3.33)
